questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of a nonhealing ulcer on her left ankle. During the past 14 years, she has had multiple ulcers over the same ankle that have subsided with wound care and dressing, which she gets from a local pharmacy. The patient has not been evaluated by a physician in 15 years. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and omeprazole. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 7.5-cm (3-in) ulcer with elevated, indurated margins and a necrotic base above the left medial malleolus. The skin around the left ankle appears darker than the right and there are multiple excoriation marks. There is 2+ pretibial edema of the lower extremities. Peripheral pulses are 3+ in all extremities. Sensation to pinprick, temperature, and vibration is normal over the lower extremities. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide topical wound care and schedule follow-up in 3 weeks
Perform sharp surgical debridement and improve glycemic control
Perform a punch biopsy of the lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is the most accurate test for diagnosing peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which can manifest with ulcers in the lower extremities. However, arterial ulcers are typically found on pressure points of the foot such as the lateral malleolus. Moreover, despite having risk factors for PAD (e.g., diabetes, obesity), this patient does not have other characteristic findings, such as absent or diminished peripheral pulses, intermittent claudication, or rest pain. Finally, DSA is an invasive and expensive procedure, and ankle-brachial index is the first-line diagnostic test for PAD.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical wound care and follow-up may be the initial approach in the treatment of certain ulcers (e.g., ulcers due to venous insufficiency or diabetic neuropathy). This patient's nonhealing skin lesion raises concern for a Marjolin ulcer, for which further management should not be delayed.

C) INCORRECT:

Sharp surgical debridement of the ulcer and improved glycemic control, both of which promote healing and decrease the risk of bacterial infection, are the initial therapy for diabetic ulcers. Diabetic foot ulcers are typically caused by peripheral neuropathy, which is unlikely in patients with a normal neurological examination of the extremities. This patient's nonhealing skin lesion raises concern for a Marjolin ulcer, which requires different management.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with peripheral edema, skin hyperpigmentation, pruritus (indicated in this case by excoriation marks), and an ulcer that is located above the medial malleolus, all of which are typical features of chronic venous disease. Endovenous thermal ablation is a definitive treatment option for patients with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) who do not respond to conservative management. Before initiating treatment for CVI, a different measure is indicated in this patient who presents with a nonhealing skin lesion that raises concern for a Marjolin ulcer.

E) CORRECT:

Marjolin ulcer is a rare but aggressive form of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) that arises from chronic wounds or scars. The progression of a chronic wound to a Marjolin ulcer is slow, with a latency period of several years to decades until malignant transformation occurs. Marjolin ulcers have a poor prognosis and require prompt diagnosis (using a punch biopsy or a wedge biopsy in patients with larger lesions) to determine further management. In addition to histologic confirmation, patients require grading and staging of the tumor.

Surgical excision of the lesion along with a margin of normal skin is the primary method of treatment; radiotherapy and/or chemotherapy may be used as adjuvants.
questions.hint: A nonhealing wound in an area of chronically damaged skin (e.g., long-standing venous ulcer) should raise concern for a Marjolin ulcer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a slowly enlarging painless ulcer on his lower lip. One year ago he had a painful rash near his upper lip that resolved completely with acyclovir therapy. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. He has worked in construction for the past 33 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The ulcer bleeds upon palpation. He has numerous moles of varying sizes all over his body. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) typically manifests with a painless, nonhealing ulcer with everted edges. Although the initial appearance can vary (e.g., plaque-like, nodular, papillomatous), all forms eventually ulcerate. SCC lesions are locally invasive and bleed easily when touched. The most important risk factor for this condition is exposure to UV light (e.g., due to chronic occupational sun exposure); sun-exposed areas of skin (e.g., the lower lip) are the most commonly affected. Other important risk factors for SCC include exposure to chemical carcinogens (e.g., coal tars via smoking), ionizing radiation, and a positive history of precancerous lesions (e.g., actinic keratosis). The diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy (e.g., punch biopsy or wedge biopsy). Once confirmed, surgical excision of the ulcer with a negative margin should be performed.

B) INCORRECT:

Superficial basal cell carcinoma (BCC) can appear as a scaly, plaque-like lesion with possible ulceration. However, superficial BCC most commonly occurs on the trunk. Nodular BCC is more common on the face but these lesions are typically pearly and nodular with central ulceration. Although BCC cannot be definitively excluded in this patient, the appearance of a nonhealing ulcer that bleeds easily in the lower lip makes a different diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Aphthous stomatitis often manifests with an ulcer on the lip. However, the ulcer is typically painful and resolves within 1–2 weeks, while this patient has had an ulcer for 3 months.
Image Description:

Two shallow spherical ulcers are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip. The borders of the ulcer are erythematous and well defined. Healthy granulation tissue is visible on the floor of the ulcers.

These aphthous ulcers are typically painful and resolve spontaneously without scarring. Aphthous stomatitis is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of aphthous ulcer formation.

D) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis can occasionally present as a nonhealing lesion on the lips. However, a typical psoriatic lesion is a well-defined, nonulcerative, pruritic, pink papule with characteristic adherent silvery-white scales. These lesions are more commonly seen on the scalp, back, elbows, and knees (extensor surfaces), and the usual age of onset is between 20–40 years of age. This middle-aged patient's nonhealing ulcer of the lip is highly unlikely to be due to psoriasis.
Image Description:

Multiple sharply demarcated confluent plaques covered with hard, coarse, silver-white scaling are visible over the extensor surface of the knee.

This is the characteristic appearance of plaque psoriasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis (SK) is the most common benign skin tumor in older adults and is frequently seen on the face. However, the typical appearance of SK is multiple sharply demarcated, greasy/waxy, darkly pigmented papules or plaques with a characteristic “stuck-on” appearance. SK lesions do not ulcerate, making it an unlikely cause of the lesion on this patient's lip.
Image Description:

Photograph of the face of an adult patient

Two large, brown, fissured papules with a characteristic stuck-on appearance can be seen.

F) INCORRECT:

A cold sore (herpes labialis) could cause an ulcerative lesion around the mouth and lips. However, this condition typically manifests with a prodrome of paresthesia and burning/stabbing pain in the affected dermatome (e.g., the mandibular/maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve if the upper/lower lip is affected), followed by numerous vesicles that have a tendency to ulcerate later. This patient presents with a single, painless ulcer without prodromal pain, making herpes labialis an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles on an erythematous base can be seen on the lower lip.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpes labialis.

G) INCORRECT:

Melanomas commonly manifest as superficial lesions on sun-exposed areas of the body. This patient has numerous risk factors for the development of melanoma such as multiple nevi and prolonged sun exposure (from working in construction). Certain uncommon variants of melanomas (acral lentiginous melanoma or advanced nodular melanoma) can also manifest as ulcerative lesions. However, a melanoma lesion most typically appears as a pruritic, pigmented macule that meets the ABCDE criteria. Furthermore, the lips and oral cavity are not common sites for melanoma.
Image Description:

Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanoma

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

H) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis of the lip (actinic cheilitis) is a precancerous lesion that typically appears on chronically sun-exposed areas of the skin in individuals with light skin who are aged over 50 years. Actinic keratosis typically manifests with scaly lesions; this patient's ulceration should raise concern for progression to malignancy.
Image Description:

Four photographs of the lips of different patients (A. B, C, D)

In all patients, there is a loss of distinction of the vermillion border either focally (lower lip in C) or circumorally.
The angles of mouth (oral commissures) are characteristically spared.

A - A brown scaly lesion is visible on the lower lip.
B - The lower vermillion border is edematous. A grayish-white macule can be seen on the lower lip. Superficial ulceration with crusting is visible on the mid-upper and lower lips. Scaling and fissuring are also visible.
C - The lower vermillion border is edematous. The lower lip appears dry and brownish scales are visible laterally.
D - Multiple brown macules can be seen.

These features depict the various presentations of actinic cheilitis, a precancerous lesion of the skin caused by chronic sun damage.
questions.hint: Biopsy of the lesion would likely show keratin pearls.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of a painless ulcer on his neck. He reports that the ulcer bleeds when lightly touched and that the application of an over-the-counter ointment has not helped it heal. He has a history of Crohn disease that is well controlled with azathioprine. He works as a landscaper in a botanical garden. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and does not drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 1-cm ulcer on the right lateral aspect of his neck. The edges of the ulcer are everted, the floor is covered with granulation tissue, and the surrounding skin is indurated. A biopsy of the ulcer shows dysplastic keratinocytes with pearls of keratin. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma is predominantly seen in individuals > 60 years of age, most likely due to cumulative damage to the DNA of skin cells resulting from prolonged exposure to carcinogenic risk factors. Advanced age, however, is not the most significant risk factor for cSCC.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppression is an important risk factor for numerous malignancies because of the decreased ability of the immune system to identify and destroy precancerous cells as well as inhibit the proliferation of malignant cells. Although immunosuppression is a risk factor for cSCC, it is not the strongest predisposing factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronically inflamed, previously traumatized, or scarred skin increases the risk of developing a Marjolin ulcer, an aggressive form of cSCC. Chronic inflammation is not, however, the strongest predisposing factor for cSCC.

D) CORRECT:

Prolonged exposure to UV light (e.g., chronic sun exposure, repetitive use of tanning beds) is the most significant risk factor for the development of most skin cancers, including cSCC. Therefore, cSCC most commonly develops on sun-exposed areas, such as the face and neck. Exposure to UV radiation damages the DNA of skin cells and causes point mutations that can result in uncontrolled proliferation of keratinocytes. Other risk factors for cSCC include smoking, chronic immunosuppression, chemical carcinogens, ionizing radiation, and chronic skin damage.
Image Description:

A solitary, partially pigmented nodule is visible on this patient's lower lip.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with light skin have a low melanin content and are therefore predisposed to developing cutaneous malignancies, like cSCC. While it augments the effect of the most significant risk factor for SCC, light skin itself is not the strongest predisposing factor for cSCC.

F) INCORRECT:

Prolonged exposure of the skin to ionizing radiation (e.g., radiotherapy for malignancy, Grenz rays for psoriasis) damages the DNA of the skin and is a risk factor for the development of cutaneous malignancies, including cSCC. Ionizing radiation is not, however, the strongest predisposing factor for cSCC.
questions.hint: A chronic nonhealing ulcer with everted edges, granulation tissue covering its base, and surrounding induration are suggestive of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). Biopsy findings of dysplastic keratinocytes with keratin pearls confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 66-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of rough skin over his forehead and the back of his hands. He has tried applying different types of moisturizers with no improvement. He has worked on a farm all his life. Physical examination shows two erythematous papules with a gritty texture and central scale over the left temple and three similar lesions over the dorsum of his hands. This patient's skin lesions increase his risk of developing a skin condition characterized by which of the following findings on histopathology?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Keratin pearls are the key histopathologic feature of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). SCC typically manifests as ulcerative, crusted, and/or scaly lesions on sun-exposed areas. It is locally invasive and can spread to the lymph nodes but rarely metastasizes. In addition to extensive sun exposure, SCC of the skin is associated with immunosuppression, chronically draining sinuses, and arsenic exposure.

Rapidly growing, nonhealing, and/or ulcerated lesions in sun-exposed areas should be biopsied to evaluate for skin cancers.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain; 10x magnification).

Keratinization of the tissue with the presence of atypical but still relatively well-differentiated cells.
A few prominent, singular nests of concentric keratin layers (keratin pearls; examples indicated by yellow overlay) are visible.

Diagnosis: cSCC

B) INCORRECT:

Horn cysts are key histopathologic features of seborrheic keratoses, which are benign, common lesions that typically manifest as greasy plaques on the trunk, upper extremities, and head in older adults. However, the actinic keratoses seen in this patient are not precursors to seborrheic keratoses.
Image Description:

Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)

Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Atypical melanocytes are key histopathologic features of dysplastic nevi and melanoma. These lesions typically manifest as irregular, pigmented macules or papules and are associated with extensive sun exposure. However, the actinic keratoses seen in this patient are not precursors to dysplastic nevi or melanoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue section (H&E stain, 200x magnification)

Green overlay: tumor cells in dermis
Black arrows: pigmented tumor cells in cornified layer of epidermis

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Noncaseating granulomas are histopathologic features of several conditions such as sarcoidosis, Crohn disease, and berylliosis. Actinic keratoses, as seen here, are not precursors to any of these conditions.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Multiple confluent granulomas (green overlay) are visible within the bronchial submucosa, narrowing the lumen (arrow). Note the absence of central necrosis in the granulomas.

This appearance is characteristic of a noncaseating granuloma in sarcoidosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Basaloid cells are key histopathologic features of basal cell carcinoma. These lesions typically manifest as waxy, erythematous, or pearly ulcerative nodules with telangiectasias, and they are associated with extensive sun exposure. However, the actinic keratoses seen in this patient are not precursors to basal cell carcinoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin tissue specimen (H&E stain; intermediate magnification)

There are dermal nests of infiltrating epithelial cells (examples indicated by green overlays) with retraction spaces between the tumor nests and the dermal fibrous tissue (dotted red lines). Furthermore, the peripheral tumor cells show palisading nuclei (examples indicated by dotted black lines).

These are the typical histologic features of basal cell carcinoma of the skin.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

F) INCORRECT:

Intraepidermal acantholysis is a key histopathologic feature of pemphigus vulgaris, which typically manifests with painful oral ulcers and flaccid blisters on the skin. Actinic keratoses, as seen in this patient, are not precursors to pemphigus vulgaris.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin biopsy sample (H&E stain) from a blister

Epidermis (purple region on the superior aspect; E):
– Suprabasal cleft (yellow overlays): A split above the basal layer of the epidermis that has led to blister formation is visible.
An unruptured blister can be seen on the right; a ruptured blister is visible on the left.
– Acantholysis: detached free-floating cells within the blisters
– Tombstone effect (green outlines): Keratinocytes of the basal layer are arranged in a single row of dark blue cells lining the inferior aspect of the blisters.
– An inflammatory infiltrate is visible through all layers of the epidermis.

Dermis (pink region on the inferior aspect; D): intact with minimal inflammatory infiltrate

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris, which is caused by a loss of desmosomes and thus cell adherence.
questions.hint: This patient has actinic keratoses on his skin associated with his extensive history of occupational sun exposure. These lesions typically manifest as rough, scaly papules on sun-exposed areas and can progress to cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 58-year-old white man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless lesion on his lower lip. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He has worked as a fruit picker for the past 25 years. His current medications include captopril and metformin. Examination of the oral cavity shows a single ulcer near the vermillion border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A chronic solitary ulcer of the lip in an older, light-skinned (white) male patient with a history of smoking and prolonged occupational sun-exposure is highly suggestive of malignancy. The most common malignancy of the lower lip is cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC), which typically manifests in chronically sun-exposed areas. 95% of malignancies of the lower lip are SCCs. SCC typically begins as a papule and then becomes a friable ulcer with everted borders that bleeds readily. Other risk factors for SCC of the lower lip include HIV and immunosuppressive therapy.
Image Description:

A solitary ulcer, approx. 2 cm in diameter, is visible on the lower lip. The inferior aspect of the ulcer appears hyperkeratotic.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpes labialis manifests with an ulcer on the lip. However, the ulcer is typically painful and resolves within 1–2 weeks, while this patient has had an ulcer for 3 months. Moreover, herpes labialis is not associated with a history of smoking, occupational sun-exposure, or light skin color.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles on an erythematous base can be seen on the lower lip.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpes labialis.

C) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris can cause chronic ulceration of the lip. The cutaneous vesiculobullous lesions that are characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris might not be present initially because oral ulceration usually precedes cutaneous lesions by several months. However, the patient would have multiple ulcers rather than a single oral ulcer, and the ulcers would be painful. Moreover, pemphigus vulgaris is not associated with a history of smoking, occupational sun-exposure, or light skin color.
Image Description:

Flaccid bullae and gray-white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

D) INCORRECT:

Aphthous stomatitis often manifests with an ulcer on the lip. However, the ulcer is typically painful and resolves within 1–2 weeks, while this patient has had an ulcer for 3 months. Moreover, aphthous stomatitis is not associated with a history of smoking, occupational sun-exposure, or light skin color.
Image Description:

Two shallow spherical ulcers are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip. The borders of the ulcer are erythematous and well defined. Healthy granulation tissue is visible on the floor of the ulcers.

These aphthous ulcers are typically painful and resolve spontaneously without scarring. Aphthous stomatitis is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of aphthous ulcer formation.

E) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis of the lip (actinic cheilitis) typically occurs on the lower lip, which is more exposed to the sun. Actinic keratosis has a higher incidence among older and light-skinned individuals, and it can cause chronic ulceration. However, an ulcer caused by actinic cheilitis would be surrounded by white or gray hyperkeratotic plaques with a rough, sandpaper-like texture, and the vermillion border would be effaced.
Image Description:

Four photographs of the lips of different patients (A. B, C, D)

In all patients, there is a loss of distinction of the vermillion border either focally (lower lip in C) or circumorally.
The angles of mouth (oral commissures) are characteristically spared.

A - A brown scaly lesion is visible on the lower lip.
B - The lower vermillion border is edematous. A grayish-white macule can be seen on the lower lip. Superficial ulceration with crusting is visible on the mid-upper and lower lips. Scaling and fissuring are also visible.
C - The lower vermillion border is edematous. The lower lip appears dry and brownish scales are visible laterally.
D - Multiple brown macules can be seen.

These features depict the various presentations of actinic cheilitis, a precancerous lesion of the skin caused by chronic sun damage.

F) INCORRECT:

Traumatic ulcers of the lower lip can be painless and manifest with ulceration of the lip, which are features seen in this patient. However, these ulcers usually resolve within 1–2 weeks, while this patient has had his ulcer for 3 months. Moreover, traumatic ulcers are typically caused by constant biting due to a psychiatric disorder, which is not seen here (e.g., delusions, mood disorders, disorganized behavior). In addition, these ulcers are not associated with a history of smoking, occupational sun-exposure, or light skin color.

G) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common cutaneous malignancy in the US. This carcinoma has a higher incidence in light-skinned individuals and tends to affect areas exposed to the sun (e.g., the lip). However, BCC is not the most common cause of lip cancer; it only accounts for approx. 5% of cases. In addition, BCC more commonly manifests on the upper lip than on the lower lip. Moreover, BCC usually has a pearly appearance and a very slow growth rate (many months to years), neither of which is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.
questions.hint: In patients with this condition, keratin pearls are common pathologic findings on biopsy.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 5-week history of a rapidly growing skin lesion near the right ear. During this time he has not noticed any bleeding from the lesion and it has not been painful or pruritic. He does not recall any trauma to the affected region. He has worked as a landscaper for 25 years. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no routine medications. A photograph of the skin lesion is shown. There is no palpable regional lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sporotrichosis results from infection with Sporothrix schenckii, which is commonly found on vegetation and garden soil and is typically transmitted via the prick of a thorn. While this patient's occupation as a landscaper puts him at risk of contracting this disease, sporotrichosis initially manifests as a papule at the site of inoculation (most commonly on extremities) followed by nodular ascending lymphangitis due to fungal spread along the lymphatic vessels. This patient's periauricular isolated nodule with a central hyperkeratotic crater is inconsistent with sporotrichosis.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Nodular melanoma (NM) is a type of rapidly growing malignant melanoma that most commonly develops on sun-exposed areas of skin in elderly individuals, like this patient. However, NM usually manifests as a dark pigmented or red (amelanotic NM) nodule that tends to ulcerate and bleed; the photograph of this patient's lesion shows an erythematous nodule with a central hyperkeratotic crater that does not bleed or ulcerate, which is inconsistent with NM.
Image Description:

Upper back

A nodular lesion (diameter approx. 4 cm) with central ulceration is visible. The border appears reddened and markedly raised.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of nodular melanoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyogenic granuloma is a benign, vascular tumor that typically manifests as a bright red lobulated papule that tends to bleed profusely after minor trauma, which is not seen here. In addition, most pyogenic granulomas develop during the second and third decades of life.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left thumb

A 2-3 cm dark red, round, shiny mass can be seen at the interphalangeal joint.

This appearance is characteristic of a pyogenic granuloma.

D) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of malignant skin tumor. It typically manifests as a nonhealing ulcer with a central depression and rolled borders on sun-exposed skin areas. Although this patient's lesion has similar features and his long-term exposure to sunlight puts him at risk for developing BCC, most BCCs are slow-growing, whereas this skin lesion developed within weeks, making BCC unlikely.
Image Description:

An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

E) CORRECT:

Keratoacanthoma is a type of skin tumor that most commonly affects middle-aged and elderly individuals with an extensive history of sun exposure, like this patient. The tumor typically develops on the face, neck, arms, or hands and manifests as a round, erythematous nodule with a central hyperkeratotic crater, as seen in the image. Keratoacanthomas grow rapidly within weeks to months and usually resolve without treatment. An excisional biopsy is usually required to confirm the diagnosis. Although keratoacanthomas are generally benign, most tumors are removed surgically because of their close resemblance to squamous cell carcinoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous angiosarcoma is a highly malignant vascular tumor that typically develops on areas of the skin exposed to radiation (e.g., radiation therapy, sunlight). This tumor manifests as multiple violaceous macules, papules, and/or subcutaneous nodules on the face and/or neck. This patient's solitary erythematous skin lesion with a central hyperkeratotic crater is inconsistent with angiosarcoma.
Image Description:

Scalp of a patient with nonhealing ulcer

An ulcerated nodule on erythematous base and surrounding crusts is visible on this patient's scalp.

These findings combined with a skin biopsy revealed cutaneous angiosarcoma, a rare but very aggressive vascular malignancy.
questions.hint: The most important differential diagnosis of this lesion is squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents with a persistent nonpruritic, slightly scaly, pink plaque on his forehead (figure). He states it has been present for at least 6 to 12 months and did not respond to 2-week trials of antifungal and glucocorticoid creams. A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation of scrapings from the lesion reveals no hyphae.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tinea faciei is a fungal infection of the face that appears as an annular scaly rash on the face, often with central clearing, and may be accompanied by small pustules or papules. Tinea faciei typically responds to empiric treatment with an antifungal cream (unless hair follicles are involved), and microscopic examination of a scraping would reveal fungal hyphae.

B) INCORRECT:

Metastatic carcinoma typically manifests with papulonodules rather than as a thin scaly plaque.

C) INCORRECT:

Melanoma can be amelanotic (showing no pigment), but rarely manifests as an erythematous, scaly plaque.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s lesion is most typical of squamous-cell carcinoma. This type of cancer typically arises in sun-exposed areas of the skin and can mimic eczematous dermatitis or tinea given the presence of scale and erythema.

Key learning point: A thin, scaling, chronic, asymptomatic plaque on the forehead that has not responded to treatment with antifungal and glucocorticoid creams most likely represents cutaneous squamous-cell carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Eczematous dermatitis is typically pruritic and responds to topical glucocorticoid preparations.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of a slowly enlarging painless ulcer on his lower lip. One year ago he had a painful rash near his upper lip that resolved completely with acyclovir therapy. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. He has worked in construction for the past 33 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The ulcer bleeds upon palpation. He has numerous moles of varying sizes all over his body. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) typically manifests with a painless, nonhealing ulcer with everted edges. Although the initial appearance can vary (e.g., plaque-like, nodular, papillomatous), all forms eventually ulcerate. SCC lesions are locally invasive and bleed easily when touched. The most important risk factor for this condition is exposure to UV light (e.g., due to chronic occupational sun exposure); sun-exposed areas of skin (e.g., the lower lip) are the most commonly affected. Other important risk factors for SCC include exposure to chemical carcinogens (e.g., coal tars via smoking), ionizing radiation, and a positive history of precancerous lesions (e.g., actinic keratosis). The diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy (e.g., punch biopsy or wedge biopsy). Once confirmed, surgical excision of the ulcer with a negative margin should be performed.

Key learning point: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip presents as a painless, nonhealing ulcer that bleeds easily and is strongly associated with chronic sun exposure and tobacco use.

B) INCORRECT:

Superficial basal cell carcinoma (BCC) can appear as a scaly, plaque-like lesion with possible ulceration. However, superficial BCC most commonly occurs on the trunk. Nodular BCC is more common on the face but these lesions are typically pearly and nodular with central ulceration. Although BCC cannot be definitively excluded in this patient, the appearance of a nonhealing ulcer that bleeds easily in the lower lip makes a different diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Aphthous stomatitis often manifests with an ulcer on the lip. However, the ulcer is typically painful and resolves within 1–2 weeks, while this patient has had an ulcer for 3 months.
Image Description:

Two shallow spherical ulcers are visible on the buccal mucosa of the lower lip. The borders of the ulcer are erythematous and well defined. Healthy granulation tissue is visible on the floor of the ulcers.

These aphthous ulcers are typically painful and resolve spontaneously without scarring. Aphthous stomatitis is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of aphthous ulcer formation.

D) INCORRECT:

A cold sore (herpes labialis) could cause an ulcerative lesion around the mouth and lips. However, this condition typically manifests with a prodrome of paresthesia and burning/stabbing pain in the affected dermatome (e.g., the mandibular/maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve if the upper/lower lip is affected), followed by numerous vesicles that have a tendency to ulcerate later. This patient presents with a single, painless ulcer without prodromal pain, making herpes labialis an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles on an erythematous base can be seen on the lower lip.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpes labialis.

E) INCORRECT:

Melanomas commonly manifest as superficial lesions on sun-exposed areas of the body. This patient has numerous risk factors for the development of melanoma such as multiple nevi and prolonged sun exposure (from working in construction). Certain uncommon variants of melanomas (acral lentiginous melanoma or advanced nodular melanoma) can also manifest as ulcerative lesions. However, a melanoma lesion most typically appears as a pruritic, pigmented macule that meets the ABCDE criteria. Furthermore, the lips and oral cavity are not common sites for melanoma.
Image Description:

Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanoma

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.
questions.hint: Biopsy of the lesion would likely show keratin pearls.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of a painless ulcer on his neck. He reports that the ulcer bleeds when lightly touched and that the application of an over-the-counter ointment has not helped it heal. He has a history of Crohn disease that is well controlled with azathioprine. He works as a landscaper in a botanical garden. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and does not drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 1-cm ulcer on the right lateral aspect of his neck. The edges of the ulcer are everted, the floor is covered with granulation tissue, and the surrounding skin is indurated. A biopsy of the ulcer shows dysplastic keratinocytes with pearls of keratin. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma is predominantly seen in individuals > 60 years of age, most likely due to cumulative damage to the DNA of skin cells resulting from prolonged exposure to carcinogenic risk factors. Advanced age, however, is not the most significant risk factor for cSCC.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppression is an important risk factor for numerous malignancies because of the decreased ability of the immune system to identify and destroy precancerous cells as well as inhibit the proliferation of malignant cells. Although immunosuppression is a risk factor for cSCC, it is not the strongest predisposing factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronically inflamed, previously traumatized, or scarred skin increases the risk of developing a Marjolin ulcer, an aggressive form of cSCC. Chronic inflammation is not, however, the strongest predisposing factor for cSCC.

D) CORRECT:

Prolonged exposure to UV light (e.g., chronic sun exposure, repetitive use of tanning beds) is the most significant risk factor for the development of most skin cancers, including cSCC. Therefore, cSCC most commonly develops on sun-exposed areas, such as the face and neck. Exposure to UV radiation damages the DNA of skin cells and causes point mutations that can result in uncontrolled proliferation of keratinocytes. Other risk factors for cSCC include smoking, chronic immunosuppression, chemical carcinogens, ionizing radiation, and chronic skin damage.
Image Description:

A solitary, partially pigmented nodule is visible on this patient's lower lip.

This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Oral squamous cell carcinoma most commonly affects the lower lip because of its direct exposure to sunlight.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with light skin have a low melanin content and are therefore predisposed to developing cutaneous malignancies, like cSCC. While it augments the effect of the most significant risk factor for SCC, light skin itself is not the strongest predisposing factor for cSCC.
questions.hint: A chronic nonhealing ulcer with everted edges, granulation tissue covering its base, and surrounding induration are suggestive of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). Biopsy findings of dysplastic keratinocytes with keratin pearls confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 60-year-old man in your clinic with a 3-month history of a slowly enlarging, painless ulcer on his lower lip. One year ago, he had a painful rash near his upper lip that resolved completely with acyclovir. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. He has worked in construction for 33 years and has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. A photograph of the lesion is provided. The ulcer bleeds when palpated. He has numerous moles of varying sizes on his body. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Melanomas commonly manifest as superficial lesions on sun-exposed areas of the body. This patient has numerous risk factors for the development of melanoma such as multiple nevi and prolonged sun exposure (from working in construction). Certain uncommon variants of melanomas (acral lentiginous melanoma or advanced nodular melanoma) can also manifest as ulcerative lesions. However, a melanoma lesion most typically appears as a pruritic, pigmented macule that meets the ABCDE criteria. Furthermore, the lips and oral cavity are not common sites for melanoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Superficial basal cell carcinoma (BCC) can appear as a scaly, plaque-like lesion with possible ulceration. However, superficial BCC most commonly occurs on the trunk. Nodular BCC is more common on the face but these lesions are typically pearly and nodular with central ulceration. Although BCC cannot be definitively excluded in this patient, the appearance of a nonhealing ulcer that bleeds easily in the lower lip makes a different diagnosis more likely.

C) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) typically manifests with a painless, nonhealing ulcer with everted edges. Although the initial appearance can vary (e.g., plaque-like, nodular, papillomatous), all forms eventually ulcerate. SCC lesions are locally invasive and bleed easily when touched. The most important risk factor for this condition is exposure to UV light (e.g., due to chronic occupational sun exposure); sun-exposed areas of skin (e.g., the lower lip) are the most commonly affected. Other important risk factors for SCC include exposure to chemical carcinogens (e.g., coal tars via smoking), ionizing radiation, and a positive history of precancerous lesions (e.g., actinic keratosis). The diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy (e.g., punch biopsy or wedge biopsy). Once confirmed, surgical excision of the ulcer with a negative margin should be performed.

Key learning point: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip presents as a painless, nonhealing ulcer with everted edges that bleeds easily, most commonly due to chronic sun exposure and smoking.

D) INCORRECT:

A cold sore (herpes labialis) could cause an ulcerative lesion around the mouth and lips. However, this condition typically manifests with a prodrome of paresthesia and burning/stabbing pain in the affected dermatome (e.g., the mandibular/maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve if the upper/lower lip is affected), followed by numerous vesicles that have a tendency to ulcerate later. This patient presents with a single, painless ulcer without prodromal pain, making herpes labialis an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Aphthous stomatitis often manifests with an ulcer on the lip. However, the ulcer is typically painful and resolves within 1–2 weeks, while this patient has had an ulcer for 3 months.
questions.hint: Biopsy of the lesion would likely show keratin pearls.

questions.text: A 70-year-old gardener presents to the ED with a 2-day history of intermittent bleeding from a lesion on the dorsum of his right hand. He reports that the lesion first appeared 7 months ago as a scaly patch but has gradually enlarged and developed crusting. He has been using an over-the-counter topical antibiotic on the lesion with no improvement. He denies trauma or systemic symptoms. Examination is shown. The lesion is not actively bleeding, and there is no fluctuance, purulence, or lymphangitic streaking. Vital signs are BP, 134/76; P, 80; R, 16; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sporotrichosis is caused by Sporothrix schenckii and typically manifests after inoculation with organic material such as a rose thorn. Sporotrichosis begins as a painless papule that ulcerates and spreads proximally along lymphatic channels, producing nodular lymphangitis. This patient's lesion is a solitary, indurated, keratinized ulcer without nodular streaking, which is inconsistent with sporotrichosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma typically manifests as a pearly papule with telangiectasia and a rolled translucent border. This patient's lesion has deep ulceration and crusting with a keratinous center, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthoma manifests as a rapidly enlarging dome-shaped nodule with a central keratin plug and often regresses spontaneously within months. The chronic course and ulcerated appearance of this patient's lesion make an alternative diagnosis more likely.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – The lesion’s indurated, ulcerated appearance with keratinous crusting on a sun-exposed site in an older man is characteristic of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. These lesions often bleed easily and may become secondarily infected. Recognition should prompt dermatological referral for biopsy and staging.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyoderma gangrenosum produces a painful ulcer with a violaceous undermined border and is usually associated with systemic inflammatory conditions. This patient's lesion has a keratinized, crusted appearance, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.

questions.text: A 72-year-old farmer presents with a non-healing lesion on his lower lip that has been present for 6 months. He notes it occasionally bleeds with minor trauma.  A photograph of the lesion is shown. There is no regional lymphadenopathy. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most significant predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Presence of a chronic, non-healing wound
Inherited defects in nucleotide excision repair

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The single most important risk factor for developing SCC is cumulative lifetime exposure to UV radiation, particularly UVB light. This patient's age and occupation as a farmer strongly support this etiology. Chronic UV exposure leads to the formation of pyrimidine dimers in DNA, causing signature mutations in tumor suppressor genes like TP53. This damage accumulates over decades, eventually leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation. Other risk factors include fair skin, immunosuppression, and chronic inflammation.

SCC typically arises on sun-exposed skin, such as the head (including ears and lip), neck, and forearms.

B) INCORRECT:

SCC can arise within sites of chronic inflammation, such as burn scars, radiation sites, or chronic non-healing ulcers (Marjolin ulcer). While this is a recognized risk factor, it is not the most significant one.

C) INCORRECT:

Inherited defects in the DNA nucleotide excision repair pathway, as seen in xeroderma pigmentosum, lead to an extreme sensitivity to UV radiation and the development of numerous skin cancers at a very early age. While this is a risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma, it is a rare genetic condition, not the most significant predisposing factor.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic immunosuppression, especially in solid organ transplant recipients, is a risk factor for cutaneous SCC. Impaired immune surveillance allows for the proliferation of malignant cells. However, it is not the most significant predisposing factor for SCC.
questions.hint: A solitary ulcer is visible on the lower lip. The inferior aspect of the ulcer appears hyperkeratotic. This finding is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Biopsy of the lesion would likely show keratin pearls.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the office for a persistent lesion on his lower lip that has been present for 4 months. He notes it has slowly enlarged and occasionally bleeds with minor trauma, like shaving. He is a retired farmer. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The lesion bleeds upon palpation. He has numerous moles of varying sizes all over his body. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Superficial basal cell carcinoma (BCC) can appear as a scaly, plaque-like lesion with possible ulceration. However, superficial BCC most commonly occurs on the trunk. Nodular BCC is more common on the face but these lesions are typically pearly and nodular with central ulceration. Although BCC cannot be definitively excluded in this patient, the appearance of a nonhealing ulcer that bleeds easily in the lower lip makes a different diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Melanomas commonly manifest as superficial lesions on sun-exposed areas of the body. This patient has numerous risk factors for the development of melanoma such as multiple nevi and prolonged sun exposure (from working as a farmer). Certain uncommon variants of melanomas (acral lentiginous melanoma or advanced nodular melanoma) can also manifest as ulcerative lesions. However, a melanoma lesion most typically appears as a pruritic, pigmented macule that meets the ABCDE criteria. Furthermore, the lips and oral cavity are not common sites for melanoma.
Image Description:

Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanoma

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

C) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) typically manifests with a painless, nonhealing ulcer with everted edges. Although the initial appearance can vary (e.g., plaque-like, nodular, papillomatous), all forms eventually ulcerate. SCC lesions are locally invasive and bleed easily when touched. The most important risk factor for this condition is exposure to UV light (e.g., due to chronic occupational sun exposure); sun-exposed areas of skin (e.g., the lower lip) are the most commonly affected. Other important risk factors for SCC include exposure to chemical carcinogens (e.g., coal tars via smoking), ionizing radiation, and a positive history of precancerous lesions (e.g., actinic keratosis). The diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy (e.g., punch biopsy or wedge biopsy). Once confirmed, surgical excision of the ulcer with a negative margin should be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis of the lip (actinic cheilitis) is a precancerous lesion that typically appears on chronically sun-exposed areas of the skin in individuals with light skin who are aged over 50 years. Actinic keratosis typically manifests with scaly lesions; this patient's ulceration should raise concern for progression to malignancy.
Image Description:

Four photographs of the lips of different patients (A. B, C, D)

In all patients, there is a loss of distinction of the vermillion border either focally (lower lip in C) or circumorally.
The angles of mouth (oral commissures) are characteristically spared.

A - A brown scaly lesion is visible on the lower lip.
B - The lower vermillion border is edematous. A grayish-white macule can be seen on the lower lip. Superficial ulceration with crusting is visible on the mid-upper and lower lips. Scaling and fissuring are also visible.
C - The lower vermillion border is edematous. The lower lip appears dry and brownish scales are visible laterally.
D - Multiple brown macules can be seen.

These features depict the various presentations of actinic cheilitis, a precancerous lesion of the skin caused by chronic sun damage.

E) INCORRECT:

A cold sore (herpes labialis) could cause an ulcerative lesion around the mouth and lips. However, this condition typically manifests with a prodrome of paresthesia and burning/stabbing pain in the affected dermatome (e.g., the mandibular/maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve if the upper/lower lip is affected), followed by numerous vesicles that have a tendency to ulcerate later. This patient presents with a single, painless ulcer without prodromal pain, making herpes labialis an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles on an erythematous base can be seen on the lower lip.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpes labialis.
questions.hint: Biopsy of the lesion would likely show keratin pearls.
